key_points: Turkey bans advertising on Twitter and Pinterest for failing to comply with a law requiring them to have a legal representative in the country.
The law, passed in October, demands social networks remove content at authorities' request and maintain a legal presence in Turkey.
Critics argue the law leads to censorship, especially after the government's media crackdown post-2016 coup attempt.
Deputy Minister of Transport and Infrastructure, Omer Fatih Sayan, defended the law as a measure against "digital fascism".
Sayan emphasized commitment to privacy and rights, stating abuse on social media is a crime, not a freedom.
Turkey threatens to reduce bandwidth for non-compliant social networks, potentially making them inaccessible.
Facebook, YouTube, and TikTok have complied with the law by appointing local representatives, reiterating support for freedom of expression.
Amnesty International and Article 19 criticize the law as a tool for state censorship and warn against Turkey acquiring user data.
Turkey has imposed fines of 40 million Turkish liras (€4.4 million) on platforms that didn't comply with the law.
The legislation was introduced shortly after President Erdoğan called for a "cleaning up" of social networks.
spokespersons: Omer Fatih Sayan (Deputy Minister of Transport and Infrastructure)
Sarah Clarke (Head of Europe and Central Asia Programme, Article 19)
